Hi,
	Further to Colin's and my earlier discussion, where we were looking for a 
way to measure how "perfect" a TTT player was, I have written some code 
that exposes a player to every possible board, and rates its response in 
terms of what would happen if it made that play against a perfect opponent, 
and then made no further mistakes.

	Yes this is limited in the sense that it makes no provision that the 
player might be playing against an imperfect opponent, but I see no 
plausible way to quantify that anyway, e.g. how many ways are there of 
being "imperfect"?  And this measure is already hideously expensive (in CPU).

	A score system such as this can be used to compare players from different 
people's projects, so I thought I'd like to throw up some definitions so 
that people can applaud or denounce, as the mood takes them...

	I propose calling this a TicTacToe Perfect Player Score (TTT-PPS).

	There are two approaches to the normalization of the boards that are 
presented to the player.  e.g, for those who didn't follow Colin and my 
discussion on this (symmetry or normalization) this is the question of 
whether you consider mirrored and or rotated versions to be the same board 
or not.  For the purposes of this test, I propose defining PPS scores for 
normalized and non-normalized data sets.  I use normalization as follows, 
when PPS is normalized you should present only the "archetypal" form of 
each board to the player.  The archetypal form is defined as follows:

	- for any given board, examine the 8 possible rotated/reflected variations 
of it, and for each one calculate an ID number as follows:

	ID = SUM(cell(i) * 3 ^ i);

	where cell(i) is:
		0 for an empty cell
		1 for a cell taken by the current player
		2 for a cell taken by the opponent

	and the sum uses i values from 0 to 8 corresponding to a board laid out as 
follows:

	0 1 2
	3 4 5
	6 7 8

	the archetype of any board is then the one with the lowest ID.

--

	There are also a few different choices for how you score each play, 
specifically:

	- how you score a player attempting an illegal move (playing on a cell 
that's already taken) - e.g. do you penalize it more than a bad but legal move

	- how you score partial success, e.g. whether you give any credit for a 
player who plays for a stalemate when a win was available

	These are not totally separate, e.g. the overall scale is arbitrary, so if 
we use a low score for illegal plays then we are effectively increasing the 
reward for partial successes.

--

	There are seven different classes of play that a player might make:

	I - illegal move attempted
	W - (eventually) leads to a win
	S move (eventually) leads to stalemate and that's the best available
	L move (eventually) leads to a loss and that's the best available
	S/W (eventually) leads to stalemate but a win was available
	L/S (eventually) leads to a lose but a stalemate was available
	L/W (eventually) leads to a lose but a win was available

	So, putting all that together and thinking it through a bit, I find only a 
few scoring schemes that really make sense

name			I	W	S	L	S/W	L/S	L/W

TTT-PPS(flat)		0	1	1	1	0	0	0
TTT-PPS(legal)	-1	1	1	1	0	0	0
TTT-PPS(nl)		0	1	1	1	.5	0	0
TTT-PPS(legal-nl)	-1	1	1	1	.5	0	0

e.g. "flat" only rewards the best possible play (in terms of PPS), "legal" 
is the same but punishes illegal moves more than bad moves, nl allows 
partial credit for Not Losing, even if you could have won, and legal-nl is 
the same but again punished illegal moves.

	Further, each of these can be "normal" or "canonical".

	Normalised tests involve 627 boards. Canonical ones have 4520 (as far as I 
have worked out so far, I could still discover some bugs)...

	Each overall score will be the average of score over all boards in the test.

--

	These scores all have the properties:
1) a "perfect" player will score 1.0000.
2) only illegal moves can drive a score negative.
3) players that cannot make illegal moves (some approaches won't allow 
this) will score the same on legal and non-legal forms.

--

	At the moment I am working up to using one of these scores as a fitness in 
a SLEAT run.  I have it all working but started with different scoring 
scheme, so I just need to settle on one of the above probably TTT-PPS(legal).

	Obviously this is not proper evolution, e.g. I'm feeding part of the 
answer into the fitness function, but it's an interesting proof-of-concept 
experiment.  If I can't make a perfect player when I'm cheating this much, 
what hope have I on a flat playing-field?

	Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
